Key Arguments: The regulation of information should not be understood as a matter of balance between tackling misinformation and freedom of speech.
Suppression of information in the name of tackling misinformation is subjective and undermines true freedom.
Freedom of thought and the ability to contribute to the marketplace of ideas is essential to liberal democracy.
The bill is seen as authoritarian and likened to Orwell's 'Ministry of Truth'.
Historical examples show that suppression of ideas can inhibit growth and prosperity.
Determining misinformation by a central authority is unreliable and biased.
True accountability comes from free and fair discussion among the general public.
Notable Quotes: Regulations that include the suppression of information and its communication in the name of 'tackling harmful online misinformation and disinformation' are problematically subjective and do away with all true freedom as soon as they are enacted.
This bill presents as a pursuit of the opposite of these ideals.
Claiming that the ACMA or anyone else's opinions and perceptions of reality are the benchmark for truth is an assertion of intellectual and moral superiority.
